about.pageDescription: Learn about the philosophy of Sentiment Inside Out and how simple analysis tools can turn market sentiment into key investment indicators, helping investors overcome fear and greed.
about.keywords: market sentiment, investment psychology, fear and greed, investment indicators, sentiment analysis, investment strategy
about.ogTitle: About Sentiment Inside Out - Market Sentiment Analysis Platform
about.heading: About Sentiment Inside Out
about.section1Text: This is a famous quote from Andr√© Kostolany, author of 'The Speculator's Confession'. Funds = Fundamentals = Macroeconomics. Psychology = Investor Sentiment = Human Nature. I believe cycles stem from human irrationality, creating the peaks and troughs of the economy and stock market.
about.section2Text: Economic data and company reports change monthly or quarterly, yet the capital market can fluctuate dramatically in short periods. This shows that sentiment's impact on price is no less than fundamentals. Some sell fearing it's too expensive; others buy fearing they'll miss out. As market participants, we should understand whether the market is currently in a state of fear or greed.
about.section3Text: I believe stock prices reflect market sentiment just as much as fundamentals. The website was founded with the goal of using simple charts and data to transform current market sentiment into important investment indicators, helping everyone overcome their irrationality and avoid chasing highs and selling lows based on emotion.
about.jsonLdDescription: Learn about the philosophy of the Sentiment Inside Out website, and how to use simple analysis tools to transform current market sentiment into important investment indicators, helping investors overcome their irrationality and avoid emotionally-driven decisions like chasing highs or selling lows.

composite.shortDescription: The Sentiment Inside Out Fear & Greed Indicator (SIO Fear & Greed Indicator) quantifies market sentiment into a score from 0 to 100. Its purpose is to gauge whether current market participants' psychology leans towards fear or greed, similar to the CNN Fear & Greed Index and the BofA Bull & Bear Indicator. It helps investors remain calm during irrational stock market volatility and avoid emotionally driven decisions like chasing highs and selling lows.

sections.title: Composite Index Explanation
sections.content: The SIO Fear & Greed Indicator is a sentiment indicator calculated from a synthesis of multiple U.S. stock market data points, represented by a score from 0 to 100. A score closer to 0 signifies extreme fear in the market, potentially indicating a higher probability of success for buying at this time. Conversely, a score closer to 100 suggests extreme greed in the market, advising against chasing further highs. Compared to the CNN Fear & Greed Index, it incorporates a more comprehensive set of indicators, including the AAII Investor Sentiment Survey results‚Äîoften considered a proxy for U.S. retail investor sentiment‚Äîto more accurately reflect the long-term relationship between market sentiment and prices.

sections.title: Historical Data Review
sections.content: Historically, whenever the Sentiment Inside Out Fear & Greed Index (SIO Fear & Greed Index) reached around 10 points, it marked a bear market bottom (including the 2009 financial crisis, the 2020 COVID-19 pandemic, and the 2022 Russo-Ukrainian War). Seizing these moments presented excellent buying opportunities.

aaiiSpread.shortDescription: The AAII Investor Sentiment Survey weekly asks members their outlook for the stock market over the next six months (bullish, bearish, neutral). The Bull-Bear Spread (bullish percentage minus bearish percentage) is a common measure of retail investor sentiment.

sections.title: Interpretation Method
sections.content: An extremely high Bull-Bear Spread (well above the historical average) usually indicates excessive market optimism and could be a potential sell signal. Conversely, an extremely low Spread (well below the historical average, even negative) indicates excessive pessimism and could be a potential buying opportunity.

sections.title: Indicator Characteristics
sections.content: This indicator reflects retail sentiment, which is often considered a contrarian indicator. Professional investors might use extreme retail sentiment for counter-trading.

cboeRatio.shortDescription: The CBOE Put/Call Ratio is an important indicator of market speculation sentiment. It calculates the ratio of traded put option contracts to call option contracts.

sections.title: Interpretation Method
sections.content: A high Put/Call Ratio (typically above 1) indicates investors are buying more puts for hedging or bearish bets, suggesting market fear. A low Put/Call Ratio (typically below 0.7) indicates investors are buying more calls for speculation or bullish bets, suggesting market greed. Using a 5-day average smooths the data for better trend observation.

sections.title: Indicator Characteristics
sections.content: Similar to the AAII survey, extremely high Put/Call Ratios often occur at market bottoms, while extremely low ratios often occur at market tops, exhibiting contrarian characteristics.

marketMomentum.shortDescription: The Market Momentum indicator measures the S&P 500 index's position relative to its 125-day moving average (approximately the half-year line). It reflects the strength of the market's medium-term trend.

sections.title: Interpretation Method
sections.content: When the S&P 500 is significantly above its 125-day MA, it indicates a strong uptrend, strong momentum, and market greed. When the index is significantly below the MA, it indicates a downtrend, weak momentum, and market fear.

sections.title: Indicator Characteristics
sections.content: Market momentum is a trend-following indicator and can be used in conjunction with other contrarian indicators (like the Put/Call Ratio) for a more comprehensive market assessment.

vixMA50.shortDescription: The VIX Index (Volatility Index), often referred to as the 'Fear Gauge,' measures the market's expectation of 30-day forward-looking volatility of the S&P 500 Index. Here, the 50-day moving average of the VIX is calculated to observe long-term trends in market sentiment.

sections.title: Interpretation Method
sections.content: An ascending VIX 50-day moving average indicates rising market fear and increased demand for hedging. Conversely, a descending VIX 50-day moving average suggests a relatively calm market, higher investor risk appetite, and a shift in market sentiment towards greed.

sections.title: Indicator Characteristics
sections.content: Extreme spikes in the VIX often accompany significant market downturns and can be considered a contrarian buy signal. Persistently low VIX levels, on the other hand, may indicate excessive greed in the market, warranting caution

safeHaven.shortDescription: The Safe Haven Demand indicator compares the difference between the total return of stocks (risk asset) and US Treasury bonds (safe-haven asset)over the past 20 trading days. It reflects the extent of fund flows into safe-haven assets.

sections.title: Interpretation Method
sections.content: When bond returns significantly outperform stock returns (low indicator value), it indicates investors are flocking to safe-haven assets, suggesting market fear. When stock returns significantly outperform bond returns (high indicator value), it indicates higher risk appetite and fund flows into risk assets, suggesting market greed.

sections.title: Indicator Characteristics
sections.content: This indicator provides a window into changes in overall market risk appetite and is an important reference for judging market sentiment.

junkBond.shortDescription: The yield spread between junk bonds (high-yield corporate bonds) and investment-grade corporate bonds reflects the market's attitude towards credit risk. Junk bonds are riskier and typically have higher yields.

sections.title: Interpretation Method
sections.content: When the spread widens (high indicator value), it means investors demand higher risk compensation to hold junk bonds. This usually happens when the market worries about economic prospects or tightening liquidity, indicating market fear. When the spread narrows (low indicator value), it means investors' risk tolerance increases, indicating market greed.

sections.title: Indicator Characteristics
sections.content: The junk bond spread is an important leading indicator for observing the health of the credit market and overall market risk appetite.

cotIndex.shortDescription: The COT Index (Commitments of Traders Index), based on the weekly report from the CFTC, measures the net position (longs minus shorts) of large speculators (often considered more informed traders) in the S&P 500 futures market relative to historical levels.

sections.title: Interpretation Method
sections.content: A COT Index near 100% indicates large speculators' net long positions are at historical highs, suggesting the market might be overly bullish and leaning towards extreme greed. An index near 0% indicates net short positions are at historical highs (or net longs are extremely low), suggesting the market might be overly bearish and leaning towards extreme fear.

sections.title: Indicator Characteristics
sections.content: Tracking the position changes of large speculators helps understand the outlook of the so-called 'smart money' on future market direction.

naaimIndex.shortDescription: The NAAIM Exposure Index (National Association of Active Investment Managers Exposure Index) surveys its members (active investment managers) weekly on their current equity market exposure level (0% = no stocks, 100% = fully invested, >100% = leveraged).

sections.title: Interpretation Method
sections.content: An extremely high exposure index (e.g., near or above 100%) indicates fund managers are generally bullish and actively holding stocks, suggesting market greed. An extremely low exposure index (e.g., near 0% or negative, indicating short positions) indicates managers are generally bearish and reducing stock holdings, suggesting market fear.

sections.title: Indicator Characteristics
sections.content: This indicator reflects the sentiment and positioning adjustments of professional investment institutions, serving as an important reference for observing the mainstream market view.

composite.intro: The SIO Fear & Greed Index is a comprehensive market sentiment indicator that integrates multiple US stock market data points into a 0-100 score, helping investors understand the current psychological state of market participants.
composite.point1: Scores closer to 0 indicate greater market fear, typically representing better buying opportunities
composite.point2: Scores closer to 100 indicate greater market greed, suggesting caution against chasing highs
composite.point3: Compared to the CNN Fear & Greed Index, it incorporates a more comprehensive set of indicators
composite.componentsDesc: This indicator integrates multiple key indicators including AAII retail surveys, CBOE Put/Call ratios, VIX volatility, market momentum, and more.

aaiiSpread.intro: The AAII Bull-Bear Spread reflects the sentiment changes of US retail investors and serves as an important contrarian indicator.
aaiiSpread.point1: Weekly survey of retail sentiment for the next six months
aaiiSpread.point2: Extremely high spreads typically occur at market tops
aaiiSpread.point3: Extremely low or negative spreads often appear at market bottoms

cboeRatio.intro: The CBOE Put/Call ratio measures speculative sentiment and hedging demand in the options market.
cboeRatio.point1: High ratios indicate investors favor defensive operations
cboeRatio.point2: Low ratios show investors have higher risk appetite
cboeRatio.point3: Uses 5-day average to smooth short-term volatility

marketMomentum.intro: The Market Momentum indicator reflects the S&P 500's position relative to its 125-day moving average, measuring medium-term trend strength.
marketMomentum.point1: Index above the moving average indicates strong upward trend
marketMomentum.point2: Index below the moving average shows clear downward trend
marketMomentum.point3: Can be combined with other contrarian indicators

vixMA50.intro: The VIX 50-day moving average reflects long-term trends in market expectations of future volatility.
vixMA50.point1: Rising trend indicates increasing market panic sentiment
vixMA50.point2: Declining trend shows relatively calm market conditions
vixMA50.point3: Extreme values often accompany important market turning points

safeHaven.intro: The Safe Haven indicator compares the relative performance of stocks versus bonds, reflecting capital flows.
safeHaven.point1: Bonds outperforming stocks indicates flight-to-safety sentiment
safeHaven.point2: Stocks outperforming bonds reflects risk appetite
safeHaven.point3: Provides important perspective on market risk preferences

junkBond.intro: The Junk Bond spread reflects market attitudes toward credit risk and liquidity conditions.
junkBond.point1: Widening spreads indicate declining market risk appetite
junkBond.point2: Narrowing spreads show increased investor risk tolerance
junkBond.point3: Leading indicator for observing credit market health

cotIndex.intro: The COT Index tracks large speculators' positioning changes in S&P 500 futures.
cotIndex.point1: Near 100% indicates large speculators are extremely bullish
cotIndex.point2: Near 0% shows large speculators are extremely bearish
cotIndex.point3: Reflects the market view of so-called 'smart money'

naaimIndex.intro: The NAAIM Exposure Index reflects professional investment managers' equity market exposure levels.
naaimIndex.point1: High exposure levels indicate institutions are generally bullish
naaimIndex.point2: Low exposure levels show institutional caution or bearishness
naaimIndex.point3: Important reference for observing institutional sentiment

composite.intro: The SIO Fear & Greed Index consists of the following eight key indicators, each providing unique market insights:

aaiiSpread.summary: US retail investor sentiment survey reflecting retail views on the market's next six months
aaiiSpread.calculation: Weekly survey of AAII members on bullish, bearish, and neutral market outlook, calculating bullish minus bearish percentage
aaiiSpread.interpretation: Extremely high values typically occur at market tops, extremely low values often appear at market bottoms, exhibiting contrarian characteristics
aaiiSpread.dataSource: American Association of Individual Investors (AAII) Weekly Investor Sentiment Survey

cboeRatio.summary: Options market speculative sentiment indicator reflecting investor hedging demand
cboeRatio.calculation: Calculates the ratio of CBOE-traded Put option contracts to Call option contracts, using 5-day moving average
cboeRatio.interpretation: High ratios (>1) indicate fear sentiment, low ratios (<0.7) indicate greed sentiment
cboeRatio.dataSource: Chicago Board Options Exchange (CBOE) options trading data

marketMomentum.summary: Measures S&P 500 index position relative to medium-term moving average, reflecting trend strength
marketMomentum.calculation: Calculates S&P 500 index deviation from its 125-day moving average
marketMomentum.interpretation: Far above average indicates strong uptrend and greed sentiment, far below indicates downtrend and fear sentiment
marketMomentum.dataSource: S&P 500 index daily closing price data

vixMA50.summary: Long-term trend of VIX volatility index, reflecting market expectations of future volatility
vixMA50.calculation: Calculates 50-day moving average of VIX index to observe long-term changes in panic sentiment
vixMA50.interpretation: Rising trend indicates increasing panic sentiment, declining trend indicates relatively calm market

safeHaven.summary: Compares stock versus bond performance, reflecting capital flows between risk and safe-haven assets
safeHaven.calculation: Compares total returns of stocks versus US Treasuries over the past 20 trading days
safeHaven.interpretation: Bonds outperforming stocks indicates flight-to-safety sentiment, stocks outperforming bonds indicates risk appetite
safeHaven.dataSource: Stock index and US Treasury price data

junkBond.summary: Spread between high-yield and investment-grade bonds, reflecting market attitude toward credit risk
junkBond.calculation: Calculates yield spread between junk bonds and investment-grade corporate bonds
junkBond.interpretation: Widening spreads indicate declining risk appetite, narrowing spreads indicate increased risk tolerance
junkBond.dataSource: High-yield and investment-grade bond yield data

cotIndex.summary: Large speculators' positioning in S&P 500 futures market
cotIndex.calculation: Based on CFTC commitment reports, calculates large speculators' net positioning relative to historical levels
cotIndex.interpretation: Near 100% indicates extreme bullishness, near 0% indicates extreme bearishness
cotIndex.dataSource: Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) weekly commitment reports

naaimIndex.summary: Professional investment managers' equity market exposure levels
naaimIndex.calculation: Weekly survey of NAAIM members on current equity market exposure percentage
naaimIndex.interpretation: High exposure indicates institutional bullishness, low exposure indicates institutional caution
naaimIndex.dataSource: National Association of Active Investment Managers (NAAIM) weekly exposure survey

tips.tip1: When the indicator shows extreme fear (0-20), it's typically a good buying opportunity
tips.tip2: When the indicator shows extreme greed (80-100), be cautious about chasing highs and consider profit-taking
tips.tip3: Observe multiple timeframes to avoid being misled by short-term fluctuations
tips.advanced1: Focus on trend changes in the indicator, not just absolute values
tips.advanced2: Combine with fundamental analysis to find fundamentally sound stocks during emotional extremes
tips.advanced3: Use the historical slider to study market performance at similar sentiment levels in the past
tips.warning1: Market sentiment indicators are auxiliary tools and should not be the sole basis for investment decisions
tips.warning2: Extreme sentiment can persist for extended periods, requiring patience for market reversals

history.patternsDesc: Through historical data analysis, we can discover important correlations between market sentiment and price movements:
history.pattern1: Extreme fear periods (0-10 points) often correspond to important market bottoms
history.pattern2: Extreme greed periods (90-100 points) frequently appear near market tops
history.pattern3: Trend changes in sentiment indicators often lead price trend changes
history.sliderDesc: Using the historical slider function on the page, you can:
history.slider1: Select specific historical periods to observe sentiment levels at that time
history.slider2: Compare the relationship between sentiment indicators and SPY prices across different periods
history.slider3: Study the impact and duration of major events on market sentiment
history.historicalReviewDesc: Here are some important historical moments and their corresponding market sentiment:
history.event2009: 2009 Financial Crisis: Index reached historical lows, followed by a long bull market
history.event2020: 2020 COVID-19 Pandemic: Sentiment deteriorated rapidly in the short term but rebounded quickly
history.event2022: 2022 Russia-Ukraine War: Geopolitical risks elevated fear sentiment
history.historicalInsight: History tells us that extreme market sentiment is often an important signal for investment opportunities.

priceAnalysis.pageDescription: Is the stock price too high or too low? Use our LOHAS Five-Line Analysis to gauge price trends and sentiment based on mean reversion and standard deviation, helping you find better entry and exit points.
priceAnalysis.keywords: LOHAS Five-Line Analysis, Price Trend Analysis, Stock Analysis, Market Sentiment, Mean Reversion, Overbought Oversold, LOHAS Channel, Standard Deviation

jsonLd.name: LOHAS Five-Line Analysis
jsonLd.description: Utilize standard deviation to analyze stock price trends and gauge market sentiment. Assess whether the current price reflects excessive optimism or pessimism. Track long-term trends and determine price position using statistical mean reversion properties.

prompt.enterSymbol: Please enter conditions and click 'Start Analysis'.

overview.title: What is the LOHAS Five-Line Analysis?
overview.content: Analyze whether the current stock price is overly optimistic or pessimistic. Utilize the statistical properties of stock price mean reversion to track long-term trends and determine the price's position.
overview.readMore: For detailed instructions, please see the article

sd.title: LOHAS Five-Line Analysis
sd.point1: The middle trend line is a long-term moving average, serving as the baseline for assessing the long-term price trend. Two standard deviations are added above and below this baseline.
sd.point2: The further the price moves from the middle trend line, the further it deviates from the long-term average, increasing the probability of reverting to the trend line.
sd.point3: When the price touches the uppermost band, it indicates a strong short-term overbought condition and extreme market optimism, posing a risk of pullback.
sd.point4: When the price touches the lowermost band, it indicates a strong short-term oversold condition and extreme market pessimism, presenting an opportunity for a rebound.

ulband.title: LOHAS Channel
ulband.point1: The LOHAS Channel is a more sensitive indicator used to help determine short-term overbought and oversold conditions.
ulband.point2: When the price breaks above the upper LOHAS Channel, it may indicate short-term overheating.
ulband.point3: When the price breaks below the lower LOHAS Channel, it may indicate short-term cooling.

tips.title: Usage Tips
tips.point1: When the price touches the uppermost or lowermost band of the LOHAS Five-Line Analysis and simultaneously breaks the LOHAS Channel, it might signify a continuation of the trend. Consider waiting for the price to return within the LOHAS Channel before taking action.
tips.point2: It is recommended for use with index ETFs or large-cap stocks with clear trends, in conjunction with fundamental analysis.
tips.point3: It should not be used as the sole basis for buy/sell decisions. Please combine with other technical indicators and fundamental analysis.

explanation.mainTitle: What is the LOHAS Five-Line Analysis?
explanation.shortDescription: Analyze whether the current stock price is overly optimistic or pessimistic. Utilize the statistical properties of stock price mean reversion to track long-term trends and determine the price's position.
explanation.readMorePrefix: For detailed instructions, please see the article:
explanation.readMoreLinkText: Analyze Price Trends and Sentiment with LOHAS Five-Line Analysis

sd.title: LOHAS Five-Line Analysis
sd.l1: The middle trend line is a long-term moving average, serving as the baseline for assessing the long-term price trend. Two standard deviations are added above and below this baseline.
sd.l2: The further the price moves from the middle trend line, the further it deviates from the long-term average, increasing the probability of reverting to the trend line.
sd.l3: When the price touches the uppermost band, it indicates a strong short-term overbought condition and extreme market optimism, posing a risk of pullback.
sd.l4: When the price touches the lowermost band, it indicates a strong short-term oversold condition and extreme market pessimism, presenting an opportunity for a rebound.

ulBand.title: LOHAS Channel
ulBand.l1: The LOHAS Channel is a more sensitive indicator used to help determine short-term overbought and oversold conditions.
ulBand.l2: When the price breaks above the upper LOHAS Channel, it may indicate short-term overheating.
ulBand.l3: When the price breaks below the lower LOHAS Channel, it may indicate short-term cooling.

combined.title: Using Both Together
combined.l1: When the price touches the uppermost or lowermost band of the LOHAS Five-Line Analysis and simultaneously breaks the LOHAS Channel, it might signify a continuation of the trend. Consider waiting for the price to return within the LOHAS Channel before taking action.
combined.l2: It is recommended for use with index ETFs or large-cap stocks with clear trends, in conjunction with fundamental analysis. It should not be used as the sole basis for buy/sell decisions.
